An index would be great, then you could prioritize your search results by how many search terms appeared in the comment.
But it will be a lot faster.
Remember to change everything to lower case before putting it in the index, too.
Using your index, you could determine which words were most frequently used in conjunction with other words.
If you recorded the offset at which you found the word, you could support a near operator, too!
You could also use your index to figure out which poster had the largest vocabulary!
Isn't that something you want to know?
You would just select from your index, the comment table, the user table, count the words, grouping by uid, and bam!
Sort it and you're good.

The sheer number of salient facts that must be addressed when planning an economy is mindboggling.
The USSR failed because it vastly underestimated the difficulty of the job.
It did have a planned economy, though.
No one person or group of people can plan the entire economy, I think that is clear.
So the job is going to need to be compartmentalized.
However, how do you divide the job?
Where do you draw the lines?
Well, how do you divide the economy into compartments of democratic control?
You can't have everyone voting on everything, so you need to cut things up somehow.
Well, that division is what's difficult.
The problem is, no matter how you cut it up, the parts still touch  effect  each other.
One processes output is another's input and all that.
Without knowledge of the rest of the process, which may be impossible due to its size, a single stage in the process has trouble making decisions that will result in the best outcome of the process.
It's a sticky problem.
alright

Exactly, what is the demand?

Well, current demand is no good for planning the future of your business.
That's my point.
You need to know what effects demand, what will cause it to change and in what way.
When you realize that you have thousands of firms, hundreds of commodities and millions of consumers, when you realize that population and firm distribution matter, that firms are competing for the same commodities, that labor is limited and must be applied towards producing what is demanded, not just directly, but also all the way up the supply chain.
when you realize all that, it's obvious that just having the facts arne't enough.
An economy is a nonlinear system with millions of variables.
It's a mathamaticians worst nightmare.
But an unplanned economy addresses relevent facts without knowing them.

I just had an idea
Well, as you probably know, I am trained and practiced in formal logic and analytic philosophy.
It would be a simple matter to prove that condemning both the WTC attacks and the US's response is logically incoherent.
I should write that.
It would be very rational and balanced.
I would systematically address relativist, utilitarian, antirealist and deontological views.
Those four right there probably cover 95% of the readers.
I don't know if I even have to prove anything.
It is incoherent for most people to condmen any act at all, given the moral views they claim to hold.
They never bother to think through it, though.
A deontological moralist would claim that the effect of an act is not pertinent to its morality, but rather the nature of an act determines its ethical quality.
For example, someone who states that murder is always wrong would fall into that catagory.
Moral absolutism is one deontological ethical system, but such systems don't have to be absolute.
You could, for instance, say that it is wrong for oneself to drink wine, but everyone else can do it.
Someone who holds such views is going to find it impossible to condemn the US attacks, though, because they will not be able to formulate a rule which both forbids the US's actions, doesn't interefere with other actions which seem obviously acceptable, and furthermore doesn't make any appeal to the outcome of the event.
The problem is that sometimes bombings are clearly okay.
You will find very few people who will agree that dropping bombs is always wrong.
Then you run into the problem of justifying your rule.
As near as I can tell, you just pulled it out of the air.
While you may find it very convincing, what commonality does it have to compel belief among others?
Plus, what about bombing innocent civilians on accident, when all proper measures have been taken to assure that only military targets are in the area?
No, you don't have to justify it to yourself.
Your belief is enough.
However, I imagine that you want others to agree with you.
What are you going to appeal to?
So bombing innocent civilians on purpose is wrong.
Your right, there isn't anyone deciding that.
Your rule has just lost any aplicability to the actual situation.
You're
I doubt that anyone is giving orders to go bomb innocent civilians.
Rather, they recognize that civilian deaths are inevitable given the proximity of civilians to military targets.
You just said that they just couldn't do it on purpose, and they aren't.
So, what is your rule now?
It's wrong to drop a bomb if the probability of hitting an innocent person goes above a particular constant?
It's never 0.
So an enemy military need only place a single civilian in each base to assure their safety from our attacks?
Does it bother you at all to find that morality must result in the inevitable death and defeat of good societies?
I don't think it does.
I can see that.
There are people who do, though.
I'm uncertain.

I will paste mine, sans links
Almost four years ago, in May 1998, India and Pakistan conducted successive test detonations of nuclear weapons.
After decades of political and military struggles over the hotly contested region of Kashmir, the uneasy neighbors stood threatening each other with doomsday devices capable of annihilating millions of lives.
Since the tests were performed, tensions in the region have only grown more strained.
During the assault on Afghanistan, the United States negotiated favorably with Pakistan for permission to use Pakistani held territory as a staging ground for military strikes deep into Taliban controlled areas.
Already disturbed by the diplomatic stance the United States  a longtime ally  was taking toward Pakistan, misgiving turned to outrage in the Indian government when a terrorist organization based in Pakistan assaulted the Indian Parliament, killing nine.
Troop buildup has since increased along the Kashmir border, and American intelligence indicates that war is imminent.
Both Indian and Pakistani officials have expressed a willingness to use nuclear weapons if necessary, and reports now indicate that at least India may indeed intend to make good on that threat.
India is presently courting the military support of Russia, which possesses the longrange missile technology that is needed for India to effectively deploy its nuclear arsenal.
Such an agreement could decisively turn the tables against Pakistan, breaking any assurance of mutual destruction, thus rendering a nuclear exchange frighteningly probable.

I would like to extend a challenge to any aspiring cryptographers in the community by announcing Kuro5hin.
org's first ever cryptography competition.
I have devised a simple encryption algorithm and used it to encrypt a small block of English text.
The first person that posts a complete solution will receive a modest prize.
For a solution to qualify, it must correctly depict the original plain text as well as a complete decryption algorithm.
Additionally, Kuro5hin.
org readers must do the majority of the work, either alone or in collaboration.
Finally, if a contestant writes a computer program to assist with the decryption, the source of the program must be provided with the solution.
Obviously, submissions that do not meet the above criteria may be posted, but they will be considered ineligible for the prize.
Without further ado, then, here is the cipher text
p><tt>
3D0972EF 4AC94719 80267487 E69749C5 ED114548 C28648E3 5E7DBE90 4C269779 240FD5B6 2E11F9AB 31F944FB 3E3A0624 F2D6E6EC
To help you on your way, here are a few hints
li> The encryption algorithm is not a substitution cipher.
li> The message was encrypted in one pass.
li> The encryption algorithm makes use of no information other than the plaintext.
li> The account used to post this story is the encrypted username of my real account.
I hope they try all sorts of things.
I'm going to end the story with this

No, what I'm going to do is point out that in most cases, it isn't humanly possible to know what exact action will result in the best consequence.
And it seems odd that humans would be incapable of acting moraly, except by accident.
So the consequentialist will reply and has replied that what makes an action right is that it has the maximum expected value.
I will point out that two properly functioning individuals may very well have different expectations regarding the same action, thus, under the second view, possibly rendering the action both right and wrong.
If the same action can be both right and wrong, we aren't really talking about neutral values anymore.
I will then tell the consequentialist to suck it.

So consequentialism begs some other moral system.

b matches a word boundry.

The Perl code might not be at fault.

rusty, is overal disk usage high?

On the database machine.
Strange.
One problem that can kill the performance on a relatively complicated DB app is if tables get aged out of the inmemory cache too quickly, requring disk access to resolve even frequently submitted queries.
But if that were the case, the machine would have steady high disk usage.
Iman, but records aren't accessed sequentially.
Iman, searched for what?
Iman, the records can only be stored sequently by a single logical ordering.
Any other access mode will absolutely blow.
I doubt K5 ever reads large blocks of sequential records, though, so it's largely moot.
K5 generally displays a bare handful of comments, which might not be in insertion order, so what's needed is good random access speed.
I'm far from dismissing it, Iman.

Well, square brackets mean one of any of these in the brackets.

certain people taking delight in misconstruing things I say and trying to

experience but also several others in general that went very badly that 
caused me to delete IRC from my computer.
I have come to realize that for 
whatever reason I have to literally watch almost every word I say outside 
of private email and messages lest it be twisted out of shape by someone 
who is either bored or on a mission from God.
I can only speculate as to the reasons why I am such a common target for 
people's aggression; honestly, besides the occasional disagreement I have 
with people, I am a very nice person and do everything I can to help those 
around me and humanity in general.
I used to be very arrogant and in those days I flamed with the best of 
In the past year, though, I've mellowed out quite a bit and become 
much more accessible to people; however, that's also made me much more 
vulnerable to personal attacks, mostly because it hurts my faith in people 
a considerable bit and I sometimes can't handle the disappointment.
I accept your apology, and I am also sorry if I did anything to offend you 
or make you uncomfortable.
I am, as I said, usually a nice person, though 
sometimes a bit more lonely than I would care to admit.
There is nothing 
you or anyone else can do about that, however.
I have no desire to return 
to the #kuro5hin chat, or use IRC in general.

anyone there who desires me to come, simply tell them that I am sorry but 
these are my wishes.

I am not going to bore you with selfrighteous cries of censorship, or demand to be restored to my place in the community, but I would ask you to briefly reflect on a few things.
While many of you have in the past condemned the discriminatory and exclusionary social structures in highschool and elsewhere, it is obvious that Kuro5hin has proven itself to be no different.

Basically, I'm arguing that the common conception of trolls is absurd.
It is ridiculous to suppose that someone would devote that much time and effort to arguing a position that they didn't believe in.
Human beings are inherently passionate about their beliefs and trolling would contradict this passion.
The reason trolling is so widly perceived, however, is that because of the intellectual relativism birthed by neoliberalism, ideas can no longer be criticised on any grounds except sincerity.
Shouting troll is the only mode of disagreement left in a neoliberal community.
That's a quick summary
